segment.source: Protect derived domain credentials with Credential Guard (Windows 10)
segment.target: Protect derived domain credentials with Credential Guard (Windows 10)

segment.source: Introduced in Windows 10 Enterprise, Credential Guard uses virtualization-based security to isolate secrets so that only privileged system software can access them.
segment.target: Introduced in Windows 10 Enterprise, Credential Guard uses virtualization-based security to isolate secrets so that only privileged system software can access them.

segment.source: Protect derived domain credentials with Credential Guard
segment.target: Protect derived domain credentials with Credential Guard

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Introduced in Windows 10 Enterprise, Credential Guard uses virtualization-based security to isolate secrets so that only privileged system software can access them.
segment.target: Introduced in Windows 10 Enterprise, Credential Guard uses virtualization-based security to isolate secrets so that only privileged system software can access them.

segment.source: Unauthorized access to these secrets can lead to credential theft attacks, such as Pass-the-Hash or Pass-The-Ticket.
segment.target: Unauthorized access to these secrets can lead to credential theft attacks, such as Pass-the-Hash or Pass-The-Ticket.

segment.source: Credential Guard prevents these attacks by protecting NTLM password hashes and Kerberos Ticket Granting Tickets.
segment.target: Credential Guard prevents these attacks by protecting NTLM password hashes and Kerberos Ticket Granting Tickets.

segment.source: Credential Guard offers the following features and solutions:
segment.target: Credential Guard offers the following features and solutions:

segment.source: Hardware security Credential Guard increases the security of derived domain credentials by taking advantage of platform security features including, Secure Boot and virtualization.
segment.target: Hardware security Credential Guard increases the security of derived domain credentials by taking advantage of platform security features including, Secure Boot and virtualization.

segment.source: Virtualization-based security Windows services that manage derived domain credentials and other secrets run in a protected environment that is isolated from the running operating system.
segment.target: Virtualization-based security Windows services that manage derived domain credentials and other secrets run in a protected environment that is isolated from the running operating system.

segment.source: Better protection against advanced persistent threats Securing derived domain credentials using the virtualization-based security blocks the credential theft attack techniques and tools used in many targeted attacks.
segment.target: Better protection against advanced persistent threats Securing derived domain credentials using the virtualization-based security blocks the credential theft attack techniques and tools used in many targeted attacks.

segment.source: Malware running in the operating system with administrative privileges cannot extract secrets that are protected by virtualization-based security.
segment.target: Malware running in the operating system with administrative privileges cannot extract secrets that are protected by virtualization-based security.

segment.source: While Credential Guard is a powerful mitigation, persistent threat attacks will likely shift to new attack techniques and you should also incorporate Device Guard and other security strategies and architectures.
segment.target: While Credential Guard is a powerful mitigation, persistent threat attacks will likely shift to new attack techniques and you should also incorporate Device Guard and other security strategies and architectures.

segment.source: Manageability You can manage Credential Guard by using Group Policy, WMI, from a command prompt, and Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: Manageability You can manage Credential Guard by using Group Policy, WMI, from a command prompt, and Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: How it works
segment.target: How it works

segment.source: Credential Guard isolates secrets that previous versions of Windows stored in the Local Security Authority (LSA) by using virtualization-based security.
segment.target: Credential Guard isolates secrets that previous versions of Windows stored in the Local Security Authority (LSA) by using virtualization-based security.

segment.source: Prior to Windows 10, the LSA stored secrets used by the operating system in its process memory.
segment.target: Prior to Windows 10, the LSA stored secrets used by the operating system in its process memory.

segment.source: With Credential Guard, the LSA process in the operating system talks to a new component called the isolated LSA process that stores and protects those secrets.
segment.target: With Credential Guard, the LSA process in the operating system talks to a new component called the isolated LSA process that stores and protects those secrets.

segment.source: Data stored by the isolated LSA process is protected using virtualization-based security and is not accessible to the rest of the operating system.
segment.target: Data stored by the isolated LSA process is protected using virtualization-based security and is not accessible to the rest of the operating system.

segment.source: LSA uses remote procedure calls to communicate with the isolated LSA process.
segment.target: LSA uses remote procedure calls to communicate with the isolated LSA process.

segment.source: For security reasons, the isolated LSA process doesn't host any device drivers.
segment.target: For security reasons, the isolated LSA process doesn't host any device drivers.

segment.source: Instead, it only hosts a small subset of operating system binaries that are needed for security and nothing else.
segment.target: Instead, it only hosts a small subset of operating system binaries that are needed for security and nothing else.

segment.source: All of these binaries are signed with a certificate that is trusted by virtualization-based security and these signatures are validated before launching the file in the protected environment.
segment.target: All of these binaries are signed with a certificate that is trusted by virtualization-based security and these signatures are validated before launching the file in the protected environment.

segment.source: Credential Guard also does not allow older variants of NTLM, unconstrained Kerberos delegation, and Kerberos authentication protocols and cipher suites when using default derived credentials, including NTLMv1, MS-CHAPv2, and weaker Kerberos encryption types, such as DES.
segment.target: Credential Guard also does not allow older variants of NTLM, unconstrained Kerberos delegation, and Kerberos authentication protocols and cipher suites when using default derived credentials, including NTLMv1, MS-CHAPv2, and weaker Kerberos encryption types, such as DES.

segment.source: Here's a high-level overview on how the LSA is isolated by using virtualization-based security:
segment.target: Here's a high-level overview on how the LSA is isolated by using virtualization-based security:

segment.source: Credential Guard overview
segment.target: Credential Guard overview

segment.source: New and changed functionality
segment.target: New and changed functionality

segment.source: To see what was added or changed in Credential Guard, see What's new in Credential Guard?.
segment.target: To see what was added or changed in Credential Guard, see What's new in Credential Guard?.

segment.source: Hardware and software requirements
segment.target: Hardware and software requirements

segment.source: The PC must meet the following hardware and software requirements to use Credential Guard:
segment.target: The PC must meet the following hardware and software requirements to use Credential Guard:

segment.source: Requirement
segment.target: Requirement

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Windows 10 Enterprise
segment.target: Windows 10 Enterprise

segment.source: The PC must be running Windows 10 Enterprise.
segment.target: The PC must be running Windows 10 Enterprise.

segment.source: UEFI firmware version 2.3.1 or higher and Secure Boot
segment.target: UEFI firmware version 2.3.1 or higher and Secure Boot

segment.source: To verify that the firmware is using UEFI version 2.3.1 or higher and Secure Boot, you can validate it against the System.Fundamentals.Firmware.CS.UEFISecureBoot.ConnectedStandby Windows Hardware Compatibility Program requirement.
segment.target: To verify that the firmware is using UEFI version 2.3.1 or higher and Secure Boot, you can validate it against the System.Fundamentals.Firmware.CS.UEFISecureBoot.ConnectedStandby Windows Hardware Compatibility Program requirement.

segment.source: Virtualization extensions
segment.target: Virtualization extensions

segment.source: The following virtualization extensions are required to support virtualization-based security:
segment.target: The following virtualization extensions are required to support virtualization-based security:

segment.source: Intel VT-x or AMD-V
segment.target: Intel VT-x or AMD-V

segment.source: Second Level Address Translation
segment.target: Second Level Address Translation

segment.source: x64 architecture
segment.target: x64 architecture

segment.source: The features that virtualization-based security uses in the Windows hypervisor can only run on a 64-bit PC.
segment.target: The features that virtualization-based security uses in the Windows hypervisor can only run on a 64-bit PC.

segment.source: A VT-d or AMD-Vi IOMMU (Input/output memory management unit)
segment.target: A VT-d or AMD-Vi IOMMU (Input/output memory management unit)

segment.source: In Windows 10, an IOMMU enhances system resiliency against memory attacks.
segment.target: In Windows 10, an IOMMU enhances system resiliency against memory attacks.

segment.source: ¹
segment.target: ¹

segment.source: Trusted Platform Module (TPM) version 1.2 or 2.0
segment.target: Trusted Platform Module (TPM) version 1.2 or 2.0

segment.source: TPM 1.2 and 2.0 provides protection for encryption keys used by virtualization-based security to protect Credential Guard secrets where all other keys are stored.
segment.target: TPM 1.2 and 2.0 provides protection for encryption keys used by virtualization-based security to protect Credential Guard secrets where all other keys are stored.

segment.source: See the following table to determine which TPM versions are supported on your OS.
segment.target: See the following table to determine which TPM versions are supported on your OS.

segment.source: OS version
segment.target: OS version

segment.source: Required TPM
segment.target: Required TPM

segment.source: Windows 10 version 1507
segment.target: Windows 10 version 1507

segment.source: TPM 2.0
segment.target: TPM 2.0

segment.source: Windows 10 version 1511
segment.target: Windows 10 version 1511

segment.source: TPM 2.0 or TPM 1.2
segment.target: TPM 2.0 or TPM 1.2

segment.source: Note If you don't have a TPM installed, Credential Guard will still be enabled, but the virtualization-based security keys used to protect Credential Guard secrets will not bound to the TPM.
segment.target: Note If you don't have a TPM installed, Credential Guard will still be enabled, but the virtualization-based security keys used to protect Credential Guard secrets will not bound to the TPM.

segment.source: Instead, the keys will be protected in a UEFI Boot Service variable.
segment.target: Instead, the keys will be protected in a UEFI Boot Service variable.

segment.source: Secure firmware update process
segment.target: Secure firmware update process

segment.source: To verify that the firmware complies with the secure firmware update process, you can validate it against the System.Fundamentals.Firmware.UEFISecureBoot Windows Hardware Compatibility Program requirement.
segment.target: To verify that the firmware complies with the secure firmware update process, you can validate it against the System.Fundamentals.Firmware.UEFISecureBoot Windows Hardware Compatibility Program requirement.

segment.source: Credential Guard relies on the security of the underlying hardware and firmware.
segment.target: Credential Guard relies on the security of the underlying hardware and firmware.

segment.source: It is critical to keep the firmware updated with the latest security fixes.
segment.target: It is critical to keep the firmware updated with the latest security fixes.

segment.source: The firmware is updated for Secure MOR implementation
segment.target: The firmware is updated for Secure MOR implementation

segment.source: Credential Guard requires the secure MOR bit to help prevent certain memory attacks.
segment.target: Credential Guard requires the secure MOR bit to help prevent certain memory attacks.

segment.source: Physical PC
segment.target: Physical PC

segment.source: For PCs running Windows 10, you cannot run Credential Guard on a virtual machine.
segment.target: For PCs running Windows 10, you cannot run Credential Guard on a virtual machine.

segment.source: ¹ If you choose the Secure Boot and DMA protection option in the Group Policy setting, an IOMMU is required.
segment.target: ¹ If you choose the Secure Boot and DMA protection option in the Group Policy setting, an IOMMU is required.

segment.source: The Secure Boot Group Policy option enables Credential Guard on devices without an IOMMU.
segment.target: The Secure Boot Group Policy option enables Credential Guard on devices without an IOMMU.

segment.source: Manage Credential Guard
segment.target: Manage Credential Guard

segment.source: Credential Guard uses virtualization-based security features that must be enabled on each PC before you can use it.
segment.target: Credential Guard uses virtualization-based security features that must be enabled on each PC before you can use it.

segment.source: Turn on Credential Guard by using Group Policy
segment.target: Turn on Credential Guard by using Group Policy

segment.source: You can use Group Policy to enable Credential Guard because it will add the virtualization-based security features for you.
segment.target: You can use Group Policy to enable Credential Guard because it will add the virtualization-based security features for you.

segment.source: From the Group Policy Management Console, go to Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice Guard.
segment.target: From the Group Policy Management Console, go to Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice Guard.

segment.source: Double-click Turn On Virtualization Based Security, and then click the Enabled option.
segment.target: Double-click Turn On Virtualization Based Security, and then click the Enabled option.

segment.source: Select Platform Security Level box, choose Secure Boot or Secure Boot and DMA Protection.
segment.target: Select Platform Security Level box, choose Secure Boot or Secure Boot and DMA Protection.

segment.source: In the Credential Guard Configuration box, click Enabled with UEFI lock, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Credential Guard Configuration box, click Enabled with UEFI lock, and then click OK.

segment.source: If you want to be able to turn off Credential Guard remotely, choose Enabled without lock.
segment.target: If you want to be able to turn off Credential Guard remotely, choose Enabled without lock.

segment.source: Credential Guard Group Policy setting
segment.target: Credential Guard Group Policy setting

segment.source: Close the Group Policy Management Console.
segment.target: Close the Group Policy Management Console.

segment.source: Add Credential Guard to an image
segment.target: Add Credential Guard to an image

segment.source: If you would like to add Credential Guard to an image, you can do this by adding the virtualization-based security features and then turning on Credential Guard.
segment.target: If you would like to add Credential Guard to an image, you can do this by adding the virtualization-based security features and then turning on Credential Guard.

segment.source: Add the virtualization-based security features
segment.target: Add the virtualization-based security features

segment.source: First, you must add the virtualization-based security features.
segment.target: First, you must add the virtualization-based security features.

segment.source: You can do this by using either the Control Panel or the Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool (DISM).
segment.target: You can do this by using either the Control Panel or the Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool (DISM).

segment.source: Note: If you enable Credential Guard by using Group Policy, these steps are not required.
segment.target: Note: If you enable Credential Guard by using Group Policy, these steps are not required.

segment.source: Group Policy will install the features for you.
segment.target: Group Policy will install the features for you.

segment.source: Add the virtualization-based security features by using Programs and Features
segment.target: Add the virtualization-based security features by using Programs and Features

segment.source: Open the Programs and Features control panel.
segment.target: Open the Programs and Features control panel.

segment.source: Click Turn Windows feature on or off.
segment.target: Click Turn Windows feature on or off.

segment.source: Select the Isolated User Mode check box.
segment.target: Select the Isolated User Mode check box.

segment.source: Go to Hyper-VHyper-V Platform, and then select the Hyper-V Hypervisor check box.
segment.target: Go to Hyper-VHyper-V Platform, and then select the Hyper-V Hypervisor check box.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Add the virtualization-based security features to an offline image by using DISM
segment.target: Add the virtualization-based security features to an offline image by using DISM

segment.source: Open an elevated command prompt.
segment.target: Open an elevated command prompt.

segment.source: Add the Hyper-V Hypervisor by running the following command:
segment.target: Add the Hyper-V Hypervisor by running the following command:

segment.source: Add Isolated User Mode by running the following command:
segment.target: Add Isolated User Mode by running the following command:

segment.source: Note: You can also add these features to an online image by using either DISM or Configuration Manager.
segment.target: Note: You can also add these features to an online image by using either DISM or Configuration Manager.

segment.source: Turn on Credential Guard
segment.target: Turn on Credential Guard

segment.source: If you don't use Group Policy, you can enable Credential Guard by using the registry.
segment.target: If you don't use Group Policy, you can enable Credential Guard by using the registry.

segment.source: Turn on Credential Guard by using the registry
segment.target: Turn on Credential Guard by using the registry

segment.source: Open Registry Editor.
segment.target: Open Registry Editor.

segment.source: Enable virtualization-based security:
segment.target: Enable virtualization-based security:

segment.source: Go to HKEYLOCALMACHINESystemCurrentControlSetControlDeviceGuard.
segment.target: Go to HKEYLOCALMACHINESystemCurrentControlSetControlDeviceGuard.

segment.source: Add a new DWORD value named EnableVirtualizationBasedSecurity.
segment.target: Add a new DWORD value named EnableVirtualizationBasedSecurity.

segment.source: Set the value of this registry setting to 1 to enable virtualization-based security and set it to 0 to disable it.
segment.target: Set the value of this registry setting to 1 to enable virtualization-based security and set it to 0 to disable it.

segment.source: Add a new DWORD value named RequirePlatformSecurityFeatures.
segment.target: Add a new DWORD value named RequirePlatformSecurityFeatures.

segment.source: Set the value of this registry setting to 1 to use Secure Boot only or set it to 3 to use Secure Boot and DMA protection.
segment.target: Set the value of this registry setting to 1 to use Secure Boot only or set it to 3 to use Secure Boot and DMA protection.

segment.source: Enable Credential Guard:
segment.target: Enable Credential Guard:

segment.source: Go to HKEYLOCALMACHINESystemCurrentControlSetControlLSA.
segment.target: Go to HKEYLOCALMACHINESystemCurrentControlSetControlLSA.

segment.source: Add a new DWORD value named LsaCfgFlags.
segment.target: Add a new DWORD value named LsaCfgFlags.

segment.source: Set the value of this registry setting to 1 to enable Credential Guard with UEFI lock, set it to 2 to enable Credential Guard without lock, and set it to 0 to disable it.
segment.target: Set the value of this registry setting to 1 to enable Credential Guard with UEFI lock, set it to 2 to enable Credential Guard without lock, and set it to 0 to disable it.

segment.source: Close Registry Editor.
segment.target: Close Registry Editor.

segment.source: Note: You can also turn on Credential Guard by setting the registry entries in the FirstLogonCommands unattend setting.
segment.target: Note: You can also turn on Credential Guard by setting the registry entries in the FirstLogonCommands unattend setting.

segment.source: Remove Credential Guard
segment.target: Remove Credential Guard

segment.source: If you have to remove Credential Guard on a PC, you need to do the following:
segment.target: If you have to remove Credential Guard on a PC, you need to do the following:

segment.source: If you used Group Policy, disable the Group Policy setting that you used to enable Credential Guard (Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice GuardTurn on Virtualization Based Security).
segment.target: If you used Group Policy, disable the Group Policy setting that you used to enable Credential Guard (Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice GuardTurn on Virtualization Based Security).

segment.source: Delete the following registry setting: HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsDeviceGuardLsaCfgFlags
segment.target: Delete the following registry setting: HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsDeviceGuardLsaCfgFlags

segment.source: Delete the Credential Guard EFI variables by using bcdedit.
segment.target: Delete the Credential Guard EFI variables by using bcdedit.

segment.source: Delete the Credential Guard EFI variables
segment.target: Delete the Credential Guard EFI variables

segment.source: From an elevated command prompt, type the following commands:
segment.target: From an elevated command prompt, type the following commands:

segment.source: Restart the PC.
segment.target: Restart the PC.

segment.source: Accept the prompt to disable Credential Guard.
segment.target: Accept the prompt to disable Credential Guard.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can disable the virtualization-based security features to turn off Credential Guard.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can disable the virtualization-based security features to turn off Credential Guard.

segment.source: Note: The PC must have one-time access to a domain controller to decrypt content, such as files that were encrypted with EFS.
segment.target: Note: The PC must have one-time access to a domain controller to decrypt content, such as files that were encrypted with EFS.

segment.source: If you want to turn off both Credential Guard and virtualization-based security, run the following bcdedit command after turning off all virtualization-based security Group Policy and registry settings: bcdedit /set {0cb3b571-2f2e-4343-a879-d86a476d7215} loadoptions DISABLE-LSA-ISO,DISABLE-VBS
segment.target: If you want to turn off both Credential Guard and virtualization-based security, run the following bcdedit command after turning off all virtualization-based security Group Policy and registry settings: bcdedit /set {0cb3b571-2f2e-4343-a879-d86a476d7215} loadoptions DISABLE-LSA-ISO,DISABLE-VBS

segment.source: For more info on virtualization-based security and Device Guard, see Device Guard deployment guide.
segment.target: For more info on virtualization-based security and Device Guard, see Device Guard deployment guide.

segment.source: Check that Credential Guard is running
segment.target: Check that Credential Guard is running

segment.source: You can use System Information to ensure that Credential Guard is running on a PC.
segment.target: You can use System Information to ensure that Credential Guard is running on a PC.

segment.source: Click Start, type msinfo32.exe, and then click System Information.
segment.target: Click Start, type msinfo32.exe, and then click System Information.

segment.source: Click System Summary.
segment.target: Click System Summary.

segment.source: Confirm that Credential Guard is shown next to Device Guard Security Services Running.
segment.target: Confirm that Credential Guard is shown next to Device Guard Security Services Running.

segment.source: Here's an example:
segment.target: Here's an example:

segment.source: System Information
segment.target: System Information

segment.source: Considerations when using Credential Guard
segment.target: Considerations when using Credential Guard

segment.source: If Credential Guard is enabled on a device after it's joined to a domain, the user and device secrets may already be compromised.
segment.target: If Credential Guard is enabled on a device after it's joined to a domain, the user and device secrets may already be compromised.

segment.source: We recommend that Credential Guard is enabled before the PC is joined to a domain.
segment.target: We recommend that Credential Guard is enabled before the PC is joined to a domain.

segment.source: You should perform regular reviews of the PCs that have Credential Guard enabled.
segment.target: You should perform regular reviews of the PCs that have Credential Guard enabled.

segment.source: This can be done with security audit policies or WMI queries.
segment.target: This can be done with security audit policies or WMI queries.

segment.source: Here's a list of WinInit event IDs to look for:
segment.target: Here's a list of WinInit event IDs to look for:

segment.source: Event ID 13 Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) was started and will protect LSA credentials.
segment.target: Event ID 13 Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) was started and will protect LSA credentials.

segment.source: Event ID 14 Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) configuration: 0x1, 0
segment.target: Event ID 14 Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) configuration: 0x1, 0

segment.source: The first variable: 0x1 means Credential Guard is configured to run.
segment.target: The first variable: 0x1 means Credential Guard is configured to run.

segment.source: 0x0 means it’s not configured to run.
segment.target: 0x0 means it’s not configured to run.

segment.source: The second variable: 0 means it’s configured to run in protect mode.
segment.target: The second variable: 0 means it’s configured to run in protect mode.

segment.source: 1 means it's configured to run in test mode.
segment.target: 1 means it's configured to run in test mode.

segment.source: This variable should always be 0.
segment.target: This variable should always be 0.

segment.source: Event ID 15 Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) is configured but the secure kernel is not running; continuing without Credential Guard.
segment.target: Event ID 15 Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) is configured but the secure kernel is not running; continuing without Credential Guard.

segment.source: Event ID 16 Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) failed to launch: error code
segment.target: Event ID 16 Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) failed to launch: error code

segment.source: Event ID 17 Error reading Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) UEFI configuration: error codeYou can also verify that TPM is being used for key protection by checking the following event in the MicrosoftWindowsKernel-Boot event source.
segment.target: Event ID 17 Error reading Credential Guard (LsaIso.exe) UEFI configuration: error codeYou can also verify that TPM is being used for key protection by checking the following event in the MicrosoftWindowsKernel-Boot event source.

segment.source: If you are running with a TPM, the TPM PCR mask value will be something other than 0.
segment.target: If you are running with a TPM, the TPM PCR mask value will be something other than 0.

segment.source: Event ID 51 VSM Master Encryption Key Provisioning.
segment.target: Event ID 51 VSM Master Encryption Key Provisioning.

segment.source: Using cached copy status: 0x0.
segment.target: Using cached copy status: 0x0.

segment.source: Unsealing cached copy status: 0x1.
segment.target: Unsealing cached copy status: 0x1.

segment.source: New key generation status: 0x1.
segment.target: New key generation status: 0x1.

segment.source: Sealing status: 0x1.
segment.target: Sealing status: 0x1.

segment.source: TPM PCR mask: 0x0.
segment.target: TPM PCR mask: 0x0.

segment.source: Passwords are still weak so we recommend that your organization deploy Credential Guard and move away from passwords and to other authentication methods, such as physical smart cards, virtual smart cards, Microsoft Passport, or Microsoft Passport for Work.
segment.target: Passwords are still weak so we recommend that your organization deploy Credential Guard and move away from passwords and to other authentication methods, such as physical smart cards, virtual smart cards, Microsoft Passport, or Microsoft Passport for Work.

segment.source: Some 3rd party Security Support Providers (SSPs and APs) might not be compatible with Credential Guard.
segment.target: Some 3rd party Security Support Providers (SSPs and APs) might not be compatible with Credential Guard.

segment.source: Credential Guard does not allow 3rd party SSPs to ask for password hashes from LSA.
segment.target: Credential Guard does not allow 3rd party SSPs to ask for password hashes from LSA.

segment.source: However, SSPs and APs still get notified of the password when a user logs on and/or changes their password.
segment.target: However, SSPs and APs still get notified of the password when a user logs on and/or changes their password.

segment.source: Any use of undocumented APIs within custom SSPs and APs are not supported.
segment.target: Any use of undocumented APIs within custom SSPs and APs are not supported.

segment.source: We recommend that custom implementations of SSPs/APs are tested against Credential Guard to ensure that the SSPs and APs do not depend on any undocumented or unsupported behaviors.
segment.target: We recommend that custom implementations of SSPs/APs are tested against Credential Guard to ensure that the SSPs and APs do not depend on any undocumented or unsupported behaviors.

segment.source: For example, using the KerbQuerySupplementalCredentialsMessage API is not supported.
segment.target: For example, using the KerbQuerySupplementalCredentialsMessage API is not supported.

segment.source: You should not replace the NTLM or Kerberos SSPs with custom SSPs and APs.
segment.target: You should not replace the NTLM or Kerberos SSPs with custom SSPs and APs.

segment.source: For more info, see Restrictions around Registering and Installing a Security Package on MSDN.
segment.target: For more info, see Restrictions around Registering and Installing a Security Package on MSDN.

segment.source: As the depth and breadth of protections provided by Credential Guard are increased, subsequent releases of Windows 10 with Credential Guard running may impact scenarios that were working in the past.
segment.target: As the depth and breadth of protections provided by Credential Guard are increased, subsequent releases of Windows 10 with Credential Guard running may impact scenarios that were working in the past.

segment.source: For example, Credential Guard may block the use of a particular type of credential or a particular component to prevent malwar efrom taking advantage of vulnerabilities.
segment.target: For example, Credential Guard may block the use of a particular type of credential or a particular component to prevent malwar efrom taking advantage of vulnerabilities.

segment.source: Therefore, we recommend that scenarios required for operations in an organization are tested before upgrading a device that has Credential Guard running.
segment.target: Therefore, we recommend that scenarios required for operations in an organization are tested before upgrading a device that has Credential Guard running.

segment.source: If you are using Wi-Fi and VPN end points that are based on MS-CHAPv2, they are subject to similar attacks as NTLMv1.
segment.target: If you are using Wi-Fi and VPN end points that are based on MS-CHAPv2, they are subject to similar attacks as NTLMv1.

segment.source: We recommend that organizations use certificated-based authentication for Wi-Fi and VPN connections.
segment.target: We recommend that organizations use certificated-based authentication for Wi-Fi and VPN connections.

segment.source: Starting with Windows 10, version 1511, domain credentials that are stored with Credential Manager are protected with Credential Guard.
segment.target: Starting with Windows 10, version 1511, domain credentials that are stored with Credential Manager are protected with Credential Guard.

segment.source: Credential Manager allows you to store credentials, such as user names and passwords that you use to log on to websites or other computers on a network.
segment.target: Credential Manager allows you to store credentials, such as user names and passwords that you use to log on to websites or other computers on a network.

segment.source: The following considerations apply to the Credential Guard protections for Credential Manager:
segment.target: The following considerations apply to the Credential Guard protections for Credential Manager:

segment.source: Credentials saved by Remote Desktop Services cannot be used to remotely connect to another machine without supplying the password.
segment.target: Credentials saved by Remote Desktop Services cannot be used to remotely connect to another machine without supplying the password.

segment.source: Attempts to use saved credentials will fail, displaying the error message "Logon attempt failed".
segment.target: Attempts to use saved credentials will fail, displaying the error message "Logon attempt failed".

segment.source: Applications that extract derived domain credentials from Credential Manager will no longer be able to use those credentials.
segment.target: Applications that extract derived domain credentials from Credential Manager will no longer be able to use those credentials.

segment.source: You cannot restore credentials using the Credential Manager control panel if the credentials were backed up from a PC that has Credential Guard turned on.
segment.target: You cannot restore credentials using the Credential Manager control panel if the credentials were backed up from a PC that has Credential Guard turned on.

segment.source: If you need to back up your credentials, you must do this before you enable Credential Guard.
segment.target: If you need to back up your credentials, you must do this before you enable Credential Guard.

segment.source: Otherwise, you won't be able to restore those credentials.
segment.target: Otherwise, you won't be able to restore those credentials.

segment.source: Kerberos Considerations
segment.target: Kerberos Considerations

segment.source: When you enable Credential Guard, you can no longer use Kerberos unconstrained delegation.
segment.target: When you enable Credential Guard, you can no longer use Kerberos unconstrained delegation.

segment.source: Unconstrained delegation could allow attackers to extract Kerberos keys from the isolated LSA process.
segment.target: Unconstrained delegation could allow attackers to extract Kerberos keys from the isolated LSA process.

segment.source: You must use constrained or resource-based Kerberos delegation instead.
segment.target: You must use constrained or resource-based Kerberos delegation instead.

segment.source: Scenarios not protected by Credential Guard
segment.target: Scenarios not protected by Credential Guard

segment.source: Some ways to store credentials are not protected by Credential Guard, including:
segment.target: Some ways to store credentials are not protected by Credential Guard, including:

segment.source: Software that manages credentials outside of Windows feature protection
segment.target: Software that manages credentials outside of Windows feature protection

segment.source: Local accounts and Microsoft Accounts
segment.target: Local accounts and Microsoft Accounts

segment.source: Credential Guard does not protect the Active Directory database running on Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview domain controllers.
segment.target: Credential Guard does not protect the Active Directory database running on Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview domain controllers.

segment.source: It also does not protect credential input pipelines, such as Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview servers running Remote Desktop Gateway.
segment.target: It also does not protect credential input pipelines, such as Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview servers running Remote Desktop Gateway.

segment.source: If you're using a Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview server as a client PC, it will get the same protection as it would be running Windows 10 Enterprise.
segment.target: If you're using a Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview server as a client PC, it will get the same protection as it would be running Windows 10 Enterprise.

segment.source: Key loggers
segment.target: Key loggers

segment.source: Physical attacks
segment.target: Physical attacks

segment.source: Does not prevent an attacker with malware on the PC from using the privileges associated with any credential.
segment.target: Does not prevent an attacker with malware on the PC from using the privileges associated with any credential.

segment.source: We recommend using dedicated PCs for high value accounts, such as IT Pros and users with access high value assets in your organization.
segment.target: We recommend using dedicated PCs for high value accounts, such as IT Pros and users with access high value assets in your organization.

segment.source: Third-party security packages
segment.target: Third-party security packages

segment.source: Digest and CredSSP credentials
segment.target: Digest and CredSSP credentials

segment.source: When Credential Guard is enabled, neither Digest nor CredSSP have access to users' logon credentials.
segment.target: When Credential Guard is enabled, neither Digest nor CredSSP have access to users' logon credentials.

segment.source: This implies no Single Sign-On use for these protocols.
segment.target: This implies no Single Sign-On use for these protocols.

segment.source: Supplied credentials for NTLM authentication are not protected.
segment.target: Supplied credentials for NTLM authentication are not protected.

segment.source: If a user is prompted for and enters credentials for NTLM authentication, these credentials are vulnerable to be read from LSASS memory.
segment.target: If a user is prompted for and enters credentials for NTLM authentication, these credentials are vulnerable to be read from LSASS memory.

segment.source: Note that these same credentials are vulnerable to key loggers as well.
segment.target: Note that these same credentials are vulnerable to key loggers as well.

segment.source: Additional mitigations
segment.target: Additional mitigations

segment.source: Credential Guard can provide mitigations against attacks on derived credentials and prevent the use of stolen credentials elsewhere.
segment.target: Credential Guard can provide mitigations against attacks on derived credentials and prevent the use of stolen credentials elsewhere.

segment.source: However, PCs can still be vulnerable to certain attacks, even if the derived credentials are protected by Credential Guard.
segment.target: However, PCs can still be vulnerable to certain attacks, even if the derived credentials are protected by Credential Guard.

segment.source: These attacks can include abusing privileges and use of derived credentials directly from a compromised device, reusing previously stolen credentials prior to Device Guard, and abuse of management tools and weak application configurations.
segment.target: These attacks can include abusing privileges and use of derived credentials directly from a compromised device, reusing previously stolen credentials prior to Device Guard, and abuse of management tools and weak application configurations.

segment.source: Because of this, additional mitigations also need to be deployed to make the domain environment more robust.
segment.target: Because of this, additional mitigations also need to be deployed to make the domain environment more robust.

segment.source: Credential theft attacks allow the attacker to steal secrets from one device and use them from another device.
segment.target: Credential theft attacks allow the attacker to steal secrets from one device and use them from another device.

segment.source: By deploying authentication policies with compound authentication in Windows Server 2012 R2 or later domains, users can be restricted to only sign on from specific domain-joined devices.
segment.target: By deploying authentication policies with compound authentication in Windows Server 2012 R2 or later domains, users can be restricted to only sign on from specific domain-joined devices.

segment.source: However, since devices also use shared secrets for authentication, attackers can steal those secrets as well.
segment.target: However, since devices also use shared secrets for authentication, attackers can steal those secrets as well.

segment.source: By deploying device certificates with Credential Guard, authentication policies can require that the device authenticates with its private key.
segment.target: By deploying device certificates with Credential Guard, authentication policies can require that the device authenticates with its private key.

segment.source: This prevents shared secrets on stolen devices to be used with stolen user passwords or Kerberos secret keys to sign on as the user.
segment.target: This prevents shared secrets on stolen devices to be used with stolen user passwords or Kerberos secret keys to sign on as the user.

segment.source: Device certificate authentication has the following requirements:
segment.target: Device certificate authentication has the following requirements:

segment.source: Device domains are Windows Server 2012 or higher and all domain controllers have certificates, which satisfy strict KDC validation (KDC EKU present and the DNS domain name matches the DNSName field of the SubjectAltName (SAN) extension).
segment.target: Device domains are Windows Server 2012 or higher and all domain controllers have certificates, which satisfy strict KDC validation (KDC EKU present and the DNS domain name matches the DNSName field of the SubjectAltName (SAN) extension).

segment.source: Windows 10 devices have the CA issuing the domain controller certificates in the enterprise store.
segment.target: Windows 10 devices have the CA issuing the domain controller certificates in the enterprise store.

segment.source: A process is established to ensure the identity and trustworthiness of the device in a similar manner as you would establish the identity and trustworthiness of a user before issuing them a smartcard.
segment.target: A process is established to ensure the identity and trustworthiness of the device in a similar manner as you would establish the identity and trustworthiness of a user before issuing them a smartcard.

segment.source: Additional Group Policy settings
segment.target: Additional Group Policy settings

segment.source: There are a few Group Policy settings that you can enable that provide more protection against credential attacks:
segment.target: There are a few Group Policy settings that you can enable that provide more protection against credential attacks:

segment.source: On the domain controllers, configure the KDC support for claims, compound authentication, and Kerberos armoring system by using Group Policy.
segment.target: On the domain controllers, configure the KDC support for claims, compound authentication, and Kerberos armoring system by using Group Policy.

segment.source: Set the KDC support for claims, compound authentication, and Kerberos armoring Group Policy setting to either Supported or Always provide claims.
segment.target: Set the KDC support for claims, compound authentication, and Kerberos armoring Group Policy setting to either Supported or Always provide claims.

segment.source: On devices running Windows 10, you can turn it on by using Group Policy as well.
segment.target: On devices running Windows 10, you can turn it on by using Group Policy as well.

segment.source: To do this, enable the Kerberos client support for claims, compound authentication and Kerberos armoringAlways send compound authentication first system Group Policy settings under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemKerberos.
segment.target: To do this, enable the Kerberos client support for claims, compound authentication and Kerberos armoringAlways send compound authentication first system Group Policy settings under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemKerberos.

segment.source: Compound authentication
segment.target: Compound authentication

segment.source: Compound authentication adds the device identity to the user’s during authentication to the domain and resources.
segment.target: Compound authentication adds the device identity to the user’s during authentication to the domain and resources.

segment.source: Without compound authentication, only the user’s secrets are validated.
segment.target: Without compound authentication, only the user’s secrets are validated.

segment.source: With compound authentication, the Kerberos client has to have both the user’s and device’s secrets.
segment.target: With compound authentication, the Kerberos client has to have both the user’s and device’s secrets.

segment.source: Enabling compound authentication also enables Kerberos armoring, which provides two additional benefits:
segment.target: Enabling compound authentication also enables Kerberos armoring, which provides two additional benefits:

segment.source: User authentication on domain-joined devices will be armored.
segment.target: User authentication on domain-joined devices will be armored.

segment.source: This means that network captures will contain encrypted Kerberos initial authentication.
segment.target: This means that network captures will contain encrypted Kerberos initial authentication.

segment.source: Without the appropriate device key, Kerberos AS-REQs are protected against offline dictionary attacks.
segment.target: Without the appropriate device key, Kerberos AS-REQs are protected against offline dictionary attacks.

segment.source: KDC errors are signed, which provides protection against error spoofing attacks.
segment.target: KDC errors are signed, which provides protection against error spoofing attacks.

segment.source: Deploying machine certificates
segment.target: Deploying machine certificates

segment.source: If the domain controllers in your organization are running Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, devices running Windows 10 will automatically enroll a machine certificate when Credential Guard is enabled and the PC is joined to the domain.
segment.target: If the domain controllers in your organization are running Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, devices running Windows 10 will automatically enroll a machine certificate when Credential Guard is enabled and the PC is joined to the domain.

segment.source: If the domain controllers are running Windows Server 2012 R2, the machine certificates must be provisioned manually on each device.
segment.target: If the domain controllers are running Windows Server 2012 R2, the machine certificates must be provisioned manually on each device.

segment.source: You can do this by creating a certificate template on the domain controller or certificate authority and deploying the machine certificates to each device.
segment.target: You can do this by creating a certificate template on the domain controller or certificate authority and deploying the machine certificates to each device.

segment.source: The same security procedures used for issuing smart cards to users should be applied to machine certificates.
segment.target: The same security procedures used for issuing smart cards to users should be applied to machine certificates.

segment.source: From the Certificate Manager console, right-click Certificate Templates, and then click Manage.
segment.target: From the Certificate Manager console, right-click Certificate Templates, and then click Manage.

segment.source: Right-click Workstation Authentication, and then click Duplicate Template.
segment.target: Right-click Workstation Authentication, and then click Duplicate Template.

segment.source: Right-click the new template, and then click Properties.
segment.target: Right-click the new template, and then click Properties.

segment.source: On the Extensions tab, click Application Policies, and then click Edit.
segment.target: On the Extensions tab, click Application Policies, and then click Edit.

segment.source: Click Client Authentication, and then click Remove.
segment.target: Click Client Authentication, and then click Remove.

segment.source: Add the ID-PKInit-KPClientAuth EKU.
segment.target: Add the ID-PKInit-KPClientAuth EKU.

segment.source: Click Add, click New, and then specify the following values:
segment.target: Click Add, click New, and then specify the following values:

segment.source: Name: Kerberos Client Auth
segment.target: Name: Kerberos Client Auth

segment.source: Object Identifier: 1.3.6.1.5.2.3.4
segment.target: Object Identifier: 1.3.6.1.5.2.3.4

segment.source: On the Extensions tab, click Issuance Policies, and then click Edit.
segment.target: On the Extensions tab, click Issuance Policies, and then click Edit.

segment.source: Under Issuance Policies, clickHigh Assurance.
segment.target: Under Issuance Policies, clickHigh Assurance.

segment.source: On the Subject name tab, clear the DNS name check box, and then select the User Principal Name (UPN) check box.
segment.target: On the Subject name tab, clear the DNS name check box, and then select the User Principal Name (UPN) check box.

segment.source: On devices that are running Credential Guard, enroll the devices using the machine authentication certificate by running the following command:
segment.target: On devices that are running Credential Guard, enroll the devices using the machine authentication certificate by running the following command:

segment.source: Note: You must restart the device after enrolling the machine authentication certificate.
segment.target: Note: You must restart the device after enrolling the machine authentication certificate.

segment.source: Link the issuance policies to a group
segment.target: Link the issuance policies to a group

segment.source: By using an authentication policy, you can ensure that users only sign into devices that are running Credential Guard.
segment.target: By using an authentication policy, you can ensure that users only sign into devices that are running Credential Guard.

segment.source: Before you deploy the authentication policy though, you must first run a couple of scripts that set up your environment.
segment.target: Before you deploy the authentication policy though, you must first run a couple of scripts that set up your environment.

segment.source: The get-IssuancePolicy.ps1 shows all of the issuance policies that are available on the certificate authority.
segment.target: The get-IssuancePolicy.ps1 shows all of the issuance policies that are available on the certificate authority.

segment.source: From a Windows PowerShell command prompt, run the following command:
segment.target: From a Windows PowerShell command prompt, run the following command:

segment.source: The set-IssuancePolicyToGroupLink.ps1 creates a Universal security group, creates an organizational unit, and links the issuance policy to that Universal security group.
segment.target: The set-IssuancePolicyToGroupLink.ps1 creates a Universal security group, creates an organizational unit, and links the issuance policy to that Universal security group.

segment.source: From a Windows PowerShell command prompt, run the following command:
segment.target: From a Windows PowerShell command prompt, run the following command:

segment.source: Deploy the authentication policy
segment.target: Deploy the authentication policy

segment.source: Before setting up the authentication policy, you should log any failed attempt to apply an authentication policy on the KDC.
segment.target: Before setting up the authentication policy, you should log any failed attempt to apply an authentication policy on the KDC.

segment.source: To do this in Event Viewer, navigate to Applications and Services LogsMicrosoftWindowsAuthentication, right-click AuthenticationPolicyFailures-DomainController, and then click Enable Log.
segment.target: To do this in Event Viewer, navigate to Applications and Services LogsMicrosoftWindowsAuthentication, right-click AuthenticationPolicyFailures-DomainController, and then click Enable Log.

segment.source: Now you can set up an authentication policy to use Credential Guard.
segment.target: Now you can set up an authentication policy to use Credential Guard.

segment.source: To add an authentication policy for Credential Guard
segment.target: To add an authentication policy for Credential Guard

segment.source: Ensure that your domain controllers are running at least the Windows Server 2012 R2 domain functional level.
segment.target: Ensure that your domain controllers are running at least the Windows Server 2012 R2 domain functional level.

segment.source: Create a security group that will be used to identify the PCs that will have this authentication policy applied to them.
segment.target: Create a security group that will be used to identify the PCs that will have this authentication policy applied to them.

segment.source: Add the computer account to this security group.
segment.target: Add the computer account to this security group.

segment.source: Open Active Directory Administrative Center.
segment.target: Open Active Directory Administrative Center.

segment.source: Click Authentication, click New, and then click Authentication Policy.
segment.target: Click Authentication, click New, and then click Authentication Policy.

segment.source: In the Display name box, enter a name for this authentication policy.
segment.target: In the Display name box, enter a name for this authentication policy.

segment.source: Under the Accounts heading, click Add.
segment.target: Under the Accounts heading, click Add.

segment.source: In the Select Users, Computers, or Service Accounts dialog box, type the name of the user account, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Select Users, Computers, or Service Accounts dialog box, type the name of the user account, and then click OK.

segment.source: Under the User heading, click the Edit button that applies to user account.
segment.target: Under the User heading, click the Edit button that applies to user account.

segment.source: Click Add a condition.
segment.target: Click Add a condition.

segment.source: In the Edit Access Control Conditions box, ensure that it reads UserGroupMember of eachValue, and then click Add items.
segment.target: In the Edit Access Control Conditions box, ensure that it reads UserGroupMember of eachValue, and then click Add items.

segment.source: In the Select Users, Computers, or Service Accounts dialog box, type the name of the security group that you created with the set-IssuancePolicyToGroupLink script, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Select Users, Computers, or Service Accounts dialog box, type the name of the security group that you created with the set-IssuancePolicyToGroupLink script, and then click OK.

segment.source: Click OK to close the Edit Access Control Conditions box.
segment.target: Click OK to close the Edit Access Control Conditions box.

segment.source: Click OK to create the authentication policy.
segment.target: Click OK to create the authentication policy.

segment.source: Close Active Directory Administrative Center.
segment.target: Close Active Directory Administrative Center.

segment.source: Note: When authentication policies in enforcement mode are deployed with Credential Guard, users will not be able to sign in using devices that do not have the machine authentication certificate provisioned.
segment.target: Note: When authentication policies in enforcement mode are deployed with Credential Guard, users will not be able to sign in using devices that do not have the machine authentication certificate provisioned.

segment.source: This applies to both local and remote sign in scenarios.
segment.target: This applies to both local and remote sign in scenarios.

segment.target: Appendix: Scripts

segment.source: Here is a list of scripts that are mentioned in this topic.
segment.target: Here is a list of scripts that are mentioned in this topic.

segment.source: Get the available issuance policies on the certificate authority
segment.target: Get the available issuance policies on the certificate authority

segment.source: Save this script file as get-IssuancePolicy.ps1.
segment.target: Save this script file as get-IssuancePolicy.ps1.

segment.source: Note: If you're having trouble running this script, try replacing the single quote after the ConvertFrom-StringData parameter.
segment.target: Note: If you're having trouble running this script, try replacing the single quote after the ConvertFrom-StringData parameter.

segment.source: Link an issuance policy to a group
segment.target: Link an issuance policy to a group

segment.source: Save the script file as set-IssuancePolicyToGroupLink.ps1.
segment.target: Save the script file as set-IssuancePolicyToGroupLink.ps1.

segment.source: Note: If you're having trouble running this script, try replacing the single quote after the ConvertFrom-StringData parameter.
segment.target: Note: If you're having trouble running this script, try replacing the single quote after the ConvertFrom-StringData parameter.
